messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Deterministic, Near-Linear 𝜀-Approximation Algorithm for Geometric Bipartite Matching

Paper Abstract: Abstract. Given point sets A𝐴A and B𝐵B in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} where A𝐴A and B𝐵B have equal size n𝑛n for some constant dimension d𝑑d and a parameter ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, we present the first deterministic algorithm that computes, in n⋅(ε−1​log⁡n)O​(d)⋅𝑛superscriptsuperscript𝜀1𝑛𝑂𝑑n\cdot(\varepsilon^{-1}\log n)^{O(d)} time, a perfect matching between A𝐴A and B𝐵B whose cost is within a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon) factor of the optimal under any ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\smash{\ell_{p}}-norm. Although a Monte-Carlo algorithm with a similar running time is proposed by Raghvendra and Agarwal [J. ACM 2020], the best-known deterministic ε𝜀\varepsilon-approximation algorithm takes Ω​(n3/2)Ωsuperscript𝑛32\Omega(n^{3/2}) time. Our algorithm constructs a (refinement of a) tree cover of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, and we develop several new tools to apply a tree-cover based approach to compute an ε𝜀\varepsilon-approximate perfect matching.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Efficient algorithms for geometric partial matching",
        "Vertical decomposition of shallow levels in 3-dimensional arrangements and its applications",
        "Faster algorithms for the geometric transportation problem",
        "Approximation algorithms for bipartite matching with metric and geometric costs",
        "A near-linear constant-factor approximation for Euclidean bipartite matching?",
        "Parallel algorithms for geometric graph problems",
        "Wasserstein generative adversarial networks",
        "On Undecided LP, Clustering and Active Learning",
        "Covering metric spaces by few trees",
        "On metric Ramsey-type phenomena",
        "Improving approximate optimal transport distances using quantization",
        "Minimum cost flows, mdps, and ℓ𝟏subscriptbold-ℓ1\\ell_{1}-regression in nearly linear time for dense instances",
        "Bipartite matching in nearly-linear time on moderately dense graphs",
        "Faster algorithms for some geometric graph problems in higher dimensions",
        "On Hierarchical Routing in Doubling Metrics",
        "Approximate nearest neighbor queries revisited",
        "On locality-sensitive orderings and their applications",
        "Similarity estimation techniques from rounding algorithms",
        "Approximating maximum weight matching in near-linear time",
        "Scaling Algorithms for Weighted Matching in General Graphs",
        "A near-linear time approximation scheme for geometric transportation with arbitrary supplies and spread",
        "Fibonacci heaps and their uses in improved network optimization algorithms",
        "The weighted matching approach to maximum cardinality matching",
        "Faster scaling algorithms for network problems",
        "Faster scaling algorithms for general graph-matching problems",
        "Oblivious network design",
        "Traveling with a Pez dispenser (or, routing issues in MPLS)",
        "Geometric Approximation Algorithms",
        "An 𝒏𝟓/𝟐superscript𝒏52n^{5/2} algorithm for maximum matchings in bipartite graphs",
        "A near linear time constant factor approximation for Euclidean bichromatic matching (cost)",
        "Dynamic planar voronoi diagrams for general distance functions and their algorithmic applications",
        "Unit capacity maxflow in almost 𝒐​(𝒎𝟒/𝟑)𝒐superscript𝒎43o(m^{4}/3) time",
        "Preconditioning for the geometric transportation problem",
        "An 𝑶~​(𝒏𝟓/𝟒)bold-~𝑶superscript𝒏54\\tilde{O}(n^{5/4}) time 𝜺𝜺\\varepsilon-approximation algorithm for rms matching in a plane",
        "Truly optimal Euclidean spanners",
        "A two-step computation of the exact GAN Wasserstein distance",
        "Navigating central path with electrical flows: From flows to matchings, and back",
        "An 𝑶​(|𝒗|⋅|𝑬|)𝑶bold-⋅𝒗𝑬{O}(\\sqrt{|v|}\\cdot|{E}|) algorithm for finding maximum matching in general graphs",
        "Combinatorial Optimization: Algorithms and Complexity",
        "Computational optimal transport",
        "A near-linear time 𝜺𝜺\\varepsilon-approximation algorithm for geometric bipartite matching",
        "The earth mover’s distance as a metric for image retrieval",
        "A sub-quadratic algorithm for bipartite matching of planar points with bounded integer coordinates",
        "Algorithms for transportation problem in geometric settings",
        "Optimal transport on discrete domains",
        "Convolutional wasserstein distances: Efficient optimal transportation on geometric domains",
        "A divide-and-conquer algorithm for min-cost perfect matching in the plane",
        "Approximation algorithms for bipartite and non-bipartite matching in the plane",
        "A proof of the MV matching algorithm",
        "Sharp asymptotic and finite-sample rates of convergence of empirical measures in Wasserstein distance"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Deterministic, Near-Linear 𝜀-Approximation Algorithm for Geometric Bipartite Matching, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
